advert.description: <br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT (DEC. 1985)</strong></font><br><blockquote>"9990 francs the TO9. Colors included" <br><br> "Thomson. All the world in a present"</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT (APRIL 1987)</strong></font><br><blockquote>"You're never so well served than by yourself..." <br><br> "...create your own micro-server on Thomson."</blockquote>

computer.description:
The Thomson TO9 had a short career and was quickly replaced with the Thomson TO9 plus.
It was designed to be a "super" Thomson TO 7-70 and has lost of its characteristics. Some options were available : RS232c and joystick connector, modem or genlock. Notice that the very first version of the TO 9 (never marketed) had a 5.25" floppy disk drive.
Contrary to the next Thomson series which have a sophisticated memory management, the TO 9 upper 64 KB ram are used as a ramdisk.
It is provided with several utilities in ROM : two basics, a word processor (paragraphe) and a data base (fiche & dossiers), there were some problems with these utilities which couldn't be easy updated.

emulator.description: Easy to use emulator, to run MO5 games without knowing MO5 commands
emulator.name: DCMO5 Gamer Edition

emulator.description: Thomson MO5NR, Thomson MO6 and Olivetti Prodest PC128 emulator for PC
emulator.name: DCMO6

emulator.description: Universal 8-bit Thomson emulator for Windows. Emulates Thomson MO5, MO5E, MO5NR, MO6, T9000, TO7/70, TO8, TO8D, TO9, TO9+ and Olivetti Prodest PC128 !
emulator.name: DCMOTO

emulator.description: Thomson T9000, TO7/70, TO8, TO8D emulator for Windows
emulator.name: DCTO7 and DCTO8

emulator.description: No, you are not dreaming. This is a TO-7/70 emulator for the Dreamcast game system !
emulator.name: TODC

item.description: 5.25'' disk drive|||320 KB model|||<br><font color="red"><strong>> 5.25'' DISK DRIVE</strong></font><br><strong>> 320 KB model</strong><br><blockquote>This 5.25'' disk-drive offers a 320 KB capacity (40 tracks > 16 sectors > 256 bytes) and a built-in controller.</blockquote>

Disk Controller|||CD 90-351|||<br><font color="red"><strong>> DISK CONTROLLER</strong></font><br><strong>> CD 90-351</strong><br><blockquote>This interface was used to connect a disk drive or a Quick Disc Drive (QDD) to a TO-7, TO-7/70, MO5 or MO6.</blockquote>
Joystick module||||||<br><font color="red"><strong>> JOYSTICK MODULE</strong></font><br><blockquote>Dual Atari compatible joysticks module</blockquote>

Music & Game Module|||CM 90-112|||<br><font color="red"><strong>> MUSIC & GAME MODULE</strong></font><br><strong>> CM 90-112</strong><br><blockquote>This module offers two joystick connectors (Videopac joysticks can be used) and adds three channels to the TO-7 or MO-5 (resulting in a total of 4 voices). Sadly, these new sound features were scarcely used in games...</blockquote>

Ordi 94|||Joystick Interface|||<br><font color="red"><strong>> ORDI 94</strong></font><br><strong>> Joystick Interface</strong><br><blockquote>This interface enables Atari joysticks to be used with TO-7, TO-7/70 and MO5. It was sold by Ordivisuel under the name Ordi 94.</blockquote>
Printer PR-90 080||||||<br><font color="red"><strong>> PRINTER PR-90 080</strong></font><br><blockquote>80 columns dot-matrix printer which was a rebadged version of the Seikosha GP-80</blockquote>

Printer PR-90 600||||||<br><font color="red"><strong>> PRINTER PR-90 600</strong></font><br><blockquote>80-column 9-pin dot matrix printer. A rebadged version of the Seikosha SP-1000 with graphics capabilities</blockquote>

computer.name: TO 9
computer.ports: Light Pen, Joystick, Mouse, Centronics, Cardridge, Audio, Bus slots (3)

shot.description: <br><font color="red"><strong>> FRONT PANEL</strong></font><br><blockquote>From left to right:<br> • ROM cartridges housing<br> • Reset switch<br> • Keyboard RJ11 plug<br> • Light pen DIN plug<br> • Tape recorder DIN plug</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> REAR SIDE</strong></font><br><blockquote><font color="blue"><b>(1)</b></font> TV aerial output, not installed on this French version<br> <font color="blue"><b>(2)</b></font> Sound output<br> <font color="blue"><b>(3)</b></font> Scart connector. A TV set or colour moniteur could be used in RGB mode<br> <font color="blue"><b>(4)</b></font> Printer connector<br> <font color="blue"><b>(5)</b></font> Connector for an external floppy drive unit<br> <font color="blue"><b>(6)</b></font> I/O module connectors (Serial interface, joysticks,...)</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> MONITOR REAR SIDE</strong></font><br><blockquote>The Thomson monitor offered a headphone output as well as numerous screen adjustments, among them one adjustment for each RGB colour.</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> INSIDE</strong></font><br><blockquote>The case was originally designed to receive a 5.25" floppy drive. The 5.25" housing have been adapted to receive a 3.5" drive just before mass production. </blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> MAINBOARD</strong></font><br><blockquote><font color="blue"><b>(1)</b></font> 128 KB RAM chips (16x4464)<br> <font color="blue"><b>(2)</b></font> Custom Thomson gate array chip<br> <font color="blue"><b>(3)</b></font> FDD controller chips. They have probably been changed at the last time, when Thomson designers chose a 3.5" FDD instead of a 5.25"<br> <font color="blue"><b>(4)</b></font> External FDD connector<br> <font color="blue"><b>(5)</b></font> Printer connector<br> <font color="blue"><b>(6)</b></font> BASICs and file management ROMs<br> <font color="blue"><b>(7)</b></font> Motorola MC6809EP processor<br> <font color="blue"><b>(8)</b></font> Motorola 6821 PIA chip<br> <font color="blue"><b>(9)</b></font> Monitor ROM<br> <font color="blue"><b>(10)</b></font> Reset switch<br> <font color="blue"><b>(11)</b></font> Motorola 6850 ACIA chip in charge of keyboard and light pen management<br> <font color="blue"><b>(12)</b></font> 6846 PIA/timer and ROM chip used, inter alia, for ROM cartridge and keyboard management<br> <font color="blue"><b>(13)</b></font> ROM cartridges connector<br> <font color="blue"><b>(14)</b></font> Switching power supply unit</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> BOOT SCREEN</strong></font><br><blockquote>When the T09 is switched on, the boot screen offers several options:<br> <b>[1]</b> "Fiches et Dossiers" database<br> <b>[2]</b> "Paragraphe" word processor<br> <b>[3]</b> Microsoft BASIC 128 KB<br> <b>[4]</b> Microsoft BASIC 1.0, TO7 compatible<br> <b>[5]</b> User adjustments<br> <b>[6]</b> Diskette files management<br><br> If a ROM cartridge is inserted, an additional option allows to run the ROM program. </blockquote>
